I have a question about leaving a rebus square until the end‚Ä¶

I often see the claim that if you want to be able to input the full rebus, you shouldn‚Äôt leave a rebus square for your last entry because as soon as you enter the first letter, it will finish the puzzle for you.

I solve on the iOS games app, and this claim doesn‚Äôt seem to be true.

I mean, if you just type a letter, instead of first tapping ‚Äúmore‚Äù and then ‚Äúrebus‚Äù to get into rebus-entry mode, then yeah, it will insert that letter and finish the puzzle without you being able to input the full rebus. But why would you do that if you know it‚Äôs a rebus?  On iOS at least, even if it‚Äôs the last square, you can enter the full rebus just fine by tapping ‚Äùmore‚Äù then ‚Äúrebus‚Äù just like you would have to with any other square if you want to enter more than a single letter.

I confirmed this today by purposefully leaving a circled rebus/Schr√∂dinger square as the last one, and I had no trouble entering it as a full rebus. I know that the way to get into rebus-entry mode is different on different platforms, but it seems that regardless of platform, once you are in rebus-entry mode, you should be able to enter the full rebus even if it‚Äôs your last square.

Is the behavior somehow different on different platforms? Thanks

This puzzle has given me an out- of-body experience. I'm sitting down and seemingly calm, but my soul is jumping up and down, in a frenzy, yelling "Bravo! Bravo!" and I can't make it stop. The solve itself was breezy, with no look-ups. Only when I was done did the awesomeness of the puzzle begin, as I unraveled the Schr√∂dinger-ness of it. My jaw dropped. My joy went through the roof. You see, I don't just find satisfaction in a successful solving experience; I derive immense joy from a constructor's genius and creativity. I can't explain it, but I simply love the feeling of being awed by another human being. And awed I was by you, Mr. Grinberg. Thank you for the joy with which you and your puzzle have filled me! (And for a little extra joy, a bit of music, of course... https://youtu.be/xuZA6qiJVfU?si=S67iVur2OnAGJTZ5)

Yes, it would likely have been an exceptionally fast Thursday even with both letters in the square‚Ä¶ but at least it would have been fairer for those who figured out the trick! Masterful feat of construction‚Ä¶ but allowing a single letter in the circled squares gifted too many with an undeserved gold! (And full disclosure, I myself did not fully earn my gold, although I did notice the double possibilities, for the most part.)

I was a little too focused on filling in the answers and the software showed me the rebuses before I had a chance to think about what the circled letters might mean.

By my estimation, at least 50% of commenters so far finished the puzzle without understanding it. (I am in that group.) This feels wrong. What is the point of having a Thursday-level trick if it can be bypassed so easily?

I am not sure who to blame for this. The puzzle creator, for not making it harder? The editors, for not placing this on a day where tricks are optional? The tech team, for not making rebus entry mandatory? Or me and my fellow solvers for just not getting it? I don‚Äôt know, but I am feeling a different kind of Schr√∂dinger effect right now: simultaneously impressed AND disappointed.

If you filled in the letters then thought 'huh too easy' without figuring out the _ or _ , then that's no problem, whatever works for you... but then don't jump in the comments and complain that it was too easy or boring.

For those who did figure out the inner workings of this puzzle but still thought it was too easy, I'd still suggest to give the constructor a bit of slack. No small feat to make this work.

Well, this is a feat par excellence.

First, sure, it‚Äôs easy to come up with pairs of words that have only a one letter difference.  But to Schr√∂dingerize them, you have to come up with a clue that naturally works for both, that doesn‚Äôt sound strained.  Here, try coming up with a clue that works with FISH and FIST, and sounds natural for both.  Take a moment, give it a stab.  

It can be a challenge, no?  (Here‚Äôs how constructor Andrew Reynolds clued them in a puzzle a year ago: ‚ÄúIt may be landed with a hook‚Äù.)

Trust me, the Times team are sticklers about this.  If it sounds strained, they will not publish it.  And today, Daniel passed that bar eight times.  

That is impressive enough, but other difficult elements ‚Äì such as the layer involving the ‚Äú_or_‚Äù words (like HORA) and the requirements of symmetry ‚Äì made this puzzle‚Äôs build a very tall hill to climb.  Truly, a beauteous bow-down-to feat.

But when I did see the solution, I was so staggered by what you did, Daniel, so enveloped in wow, that the payoff was more than sufficient.  Thank you for that and for all you put into this.  I‚Äôll remember this one for a long time!

I agree with the majority that this was both brilliant and frustratingly easy to get the gold star without being required to understand the brilliance. I stand by my yesterday‚Äôs comment:  If you have to think ‚Äúrebus‚Äù then you should have to place a rebus! In this case, require an h and a!

The puzzle has 17 possible solutions (16 single letter solutions and one rebus solution).  That arguably makes it the easiest NYT crossword ever.  The rebus solution is the only true solution, however.  If you didn't get it prior to the happy music, you were generously given a time and credit for, in essence, a partial solution.  Such was my lot.  But I feel the circle squares and the clues referencing them was ample suggestion for the rebus solution.  If this had been the only accepted solution however, the complaints would have been a quantum leap above the "too easy" gripes.  So kudos to Daniel and Will and team for a superlative cruciverbal achievement.

In a Schr√∂dinger puzzle, there are two alternatives, each of which makes a correct answer. In the famous Clinton/Dole puzzle of 1996, CAT or BAT were clued as an unlucky black animal or something similar. Either letter, C or B works. Not both. Get it?  I‚Äôll say it again, not both.
